vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/c2a5e901-5e16-4a3e-90c0-7b9870683d7f">WALES</keyword>         <topcClas>Housing</topcClas>         <topcClas>Social attitudes and behaviour - Society and culture</topcClas>         <topcClas>Social indicators and quality of life - Society and culture</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>The <i>Living in Wales</i> (LIW) survey series, which ran from 2004-2008, was the main general source of statistical information about households and the condition of homes in Wales.  The LIW survey was also referred to as the <i>Welsh Household and Dwelling Survey</i> and replaced the former <i>Welsh House Condition Survey</i> (WHCS), which was last conducted in 1997 and 1998, when a Household Survey was completed in 1997 and a Property Survey in 1998.<br> <br> The LIW survey had two separate but linked components: the Household Survey and the Property Survey.  The Household Survey was completed annually from 2004 and was conducted as a face-to-face interview with the household reference person (HRP) or another appropriate adult. It aimed to provide additional information to complement the Property Survey, but also to provide information about the community, the use of the Welsh language, the health of the members of the household, the values and opinions of the respondent as well as demographic characteristics. The Property Survey was conducted in 2004 and 2008 (held under SNs 7201 and 7202 respectively) and comprised an internal and external assessment of the property which was completed by a qualified surveyor. <br> <br> The <i>Living in Wales</i> survey closed in 2008.  From 2009/2010 onwards, it has been replaced by the <i>National Survey for Wales</i> (held at the Archive under GN 33435). Further information can be found on the Welsh Assembly Government <a href="http://wales.gov.uk/about/aboutresearch/social/ocsropage/living-wales/?lang=en" title="Living in Wales">Living in Wales</a> web page.<br> </abstract>       <abstract>For the second edition (July 2013), a new version of the fuel poverty file was deposited. The previous version had included 2008 data in error.<br> <br> </abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br>The 2004 Property Survey covered: the Welsh Housing Quality Standard (WHQS); repair costs; fuel poverty; Housing Health and Safety Rating System (HHSRS); energy efficiency and Standard Assessment Procedure (SAP).</abstract>       <sumDscr>         <collDate event="start" date="2004-03-01T00:00:00Z">March 2004</collDate>         <collDate event="end" date="2004-10-01T00:00:00Z">October 2004</collDate>         <nation>Wales</nation>         <geogUnit>Countries</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Individuals</anlyUnit>         <anlyUnit> Families/households</anlyUnit>         <universe>National</universe>         <universe>Private households in Wales, 2004</universe>         <dataKind>Numeric data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Individual (micro) level</dataKind>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Repeated cross-sectional study</timeMeth>         <dataCollector>Ipsos MORI</dataCollector>         <dataCollector>GfK NOP</dataCollector>         <sampProc>Multi-stage stratified random sample</sampProc>         <sampProc>Addresses for the household interviews were selected from the Postcode Address File (PAF) and were stratified by local authority. Property survey addresses were selected from successful household interviews and were further stratified by first impression of the external condition, using the 'Good, bad and ugly' approach. Properties included were occupied first homes and where multiple households occupied the same property only the first household was included in the property survey sample. The results are available at Wales level only.</sampProc>         <deviat>2,466 properties</deviat>         <collMode>Physical measurements</collMode>         <collMode>The property surveys were completed by trained surveyors using paper forms. The property survey took place at a separate time to the household interview.</collMode>         <sources />         <weight>Weighting used. See documentation for details</weight>         <cleanOps>A</cleanOps>       </dataColl>     </method>     <dataAccs>       <setAvail>         <accsPlac>UK Data Service</accsPlac>       </setAvail>       <useStmt>         <specPerm>Standard conditions of access</specPerm>         <restrctn>The depositor has specified that registration is required and standard conditions of use apply. The depositor may be informed about usage. See <a href=http://ukdataservice.ac.uk/get-data/how-to-access/conditions.aspx>terms and conditions of access</a> for further information.</restrctn>         <contact><a href=http://www.ukdataservice.ac.uk/help/get-in-touch.aspx>Get in touch</a></contact>       </useStmt>     </dataAccs>     <othrStdyMat>       <relStdy>6129 Living in Wales: Household Survey, 2004 </relStdy>       <relStdy>6130 Living in Wales: Household Survey, 2005 </relStdy>       <relStdy>6131 Living in Wales: Household Survey, 2006 </relStdy>       <relStdy>6132 Living in Wales: Household Survey, 2007 </relStdy>       <relStdy>6351 Living in Wales: Household Survey, 2008 </relStdy>       <relStdy>6352 Living in Wales: Household Survey; 2004  and 2005 Combined Data Files </relStdy>       <relStdy>6353 Living in Wales: Household Survey; 2004, 2005 and 2006 Combined Data Files </relStdy>       <relStdy>6354 Living in Wales: Household Survey; 2005, 2006 and 2007 Combined Data Files </relStdy>       <relStdy>6355 Living in Wales: Household Survey; 2006, 2007 and 2008 Combined Data Files </relStdy>       <relStdy>7202 Living in Wales: Property Survey, 2008 </relStdy>       <relStdy>3435 Welsh Social Survey, 1992; Including Welsh House Condition Survey, 1992 </relStdy>       <relStdy>7477 Welsh Language Use Surveys, 2004-2006 </relStdy>       <relPubl>Publications and results may be found on the Welsh Assembly Government\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Living in Wales <a href="http://wales.gov.uk/about/aboutresearch/social/ocsropage/living-wales/results/?lang=en" title ="Living in Wales Survey Results">Survey Results</a> web page.<br> <br> Swires-Hennessy, E. and Thomas, G.W. (1987) 'The good, the bad and the ugly: multiple stratified sampling in the 1986 Welsh House Condition Survey', <i>Statistical News</i>, 79, pp.24-26.<br></relPubl>       <relPubl>Equality and Human Rights Commission (2013) <i>Standard of Living</i>, Measurement Framework Series Briefing Paper no.10, Manchester: Equality and Human Rights Commission.
